I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Highlighting “knowledge solutions” as a strategic priority, the Midterm Review of Strategy 
2020  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  identified  the  need  to  strengthen  knowledge 
management to meet the demands of ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs) through 
stronger  institutional  coordination.  This  would  better  capture  the  knowledge  embedded  in 
operations and ensure that the knowledge generated outside operations flows back to shape 
future operations.1 ADB’s midterm review also called for the adoption of a “One ADB” approach 
to knowledge solutions by closely integrating knowledge operations with country operations. A 
key  means  to  operationalize  this  approach  is  the  increased  involvement  of  the  recently 
established sector and thematic groups (STGs) in project development, and preparation of 
knowledge products and services (KPS) to reflect DMC demands and support ADB operations.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The development issue at the core of this technical assistance (TA) is the need to 
provide  DMCs  with  more  and  better  knowledge  solutions  to  help  achieve  sustainable 
development and manage matters related to environment and climate change. ADB’s midterm 
review  recognizes  the  fast-changing  development  landscape  and  that  most  DMCs  have 
achieved, or are expected to achieve, middle-income status by 2020. For one, DMCs are now 
more closely integrated and connected thanks to improved infrastructure and information and 
communication technology. These developments necessitate enhanced knowledge support for 
ADB’s lending and nonlending activities. Further, several events in 2015—(i) Third International 
Conference  on  Financing  for  Development  in  Addis  Ababa  in  July,  (ii)  adoption  of  the 
Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) during the United Nations’ annual meeting in New York 
in  September,  and  (iii)  the  21st  Conference  of  the  Parties  in  Paris  in  December—have 
significantly changed or will change the development landscape in the region, and require ADB 
to respond better and faster to DMC needs.3 
 
3.  The nature of the challenges faced by DMCs continues to evolve and clients increasingly 
demand  Finance++  solutions—financing  matched  with  knowledge  solutions  and  faster  and 
better coordinated delivery of knowledge solutions. This evolution is reflected in the areas 
specified for DMC knowledge support in (i) ADB country partnership strategies, (ii) country 
knowledge plans (CKPs), (iii) lists of indicative knowledge products and events, and (iv) work 
plans of the STGs. The preparation of CKPs provides a mechanism for more consultations and 
coordination with ADB’s operations departments and its resident missions, and informs the work 
of the STGs. The following figure illustrates the parties, relationships, and flows involved in 
delivering DMC-driven knowledge.

4.  The TA will support the implementation of ADB’s knowledge management strategy, and 
help tackle some critical weaknesses in ADB’s delivery of knowledge solutions to its DMCs. For 
one, project-specific efforts are not being linked to each other to ensure that knowledge flows 
from one DMC to another. Second, the flow of information is insufficient to understand and 
respond to knowledge demand and supply by DMCs across the boundaries of ADB’s operations 
departments, which creates a “silo” reality.4 As confirmed in ADB’s recent 2015 top task survey, 
ADB is valued for its knowledge sharing but the respondents, including DMCs, commented that 
ADB’s “knowledge offerings are not such a good match for what they want.”5 Helping to break 
these silos, offer better matches, and accelerate the information flow, the TA will ensure that 
knowledge solutions developed under it will be leveraged, shared, and disseminated through 
various means, including ADB’s k-Portal and k-Learn knowledge platforms, as well as sector 
and thematic training programs (including co-learning programs involving both DMC officials 
and ADB staff), such as the Asia Leadership Program on Sustainable Development and Climate 
Change.6 
 
5.  After consultations with ADB’s operations departments, including resident missions and 
STGs, in particular during the formulation of their 3-year rolling work priorities and programs, the 
TA will target support in the following areas: (i) cross-sector, nexus, and crosscutting work (e.g., 
sustainable and smart cities; smart green infrastructure; food–energy–water–climate nexus;

gender and sustainable cities; mainstreaming of governance and capacity development into 
sector  operations;  natural  resource  management;  public–private  partnerships  and  capacity 
development in sector operations, as well as energy, health, social protection, and/or urban 
interconnected issues); (ii) new areas and approaches reflecting recent developments, such as 
the SDGs and climate change agenda; (iii) continuous learning, networking, and knowledge 
sharing with DMCs, including through co-learning programs, in partnership with k-hubs, centers 
of excellence (COEs), and external partners; and (iv) promotion of global and regional best 
practices for application in DMCs. Given the extent and urgency of DMC demand in these areas, 
however, many are currently under-resourced. 
6. By  supporting  these  new  knowledge  priorities  of  the  STGs  and  ADB’s  operations
departments, the TA will respond to the suggestions from the Knowledge Management Action 
Plan and Knowledge Operations Review meetings that ADB use its operations cycle to ensure 
that its knowledge solutions are relevant to DMCs and can be incorporated into operations. 
Taking into account the flows and links between the various parties (see the figure above), the 
TA will help ADB to deliver DMC-driven knowledge. One key need to be addressed by the TA is 
supporting resident mission  country  directors  deliver  just-in-time  KPS,  particularly  requiring 
technical expertise, so that they can carry out their role as “knowledge custodians” in the design 
and implementation of CKPs. 
III. THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7. The impact will be that more integrated development solutions and services in DMCs are
implemented.  The  outcome  will  be  that  more  crosscutting  and  demand-driven  knowledge 
solutions for DMCs are adopted. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8. The TA will support DMCs in the priority areas described in para. 5 and, based on
indicative proposals from the STGs and operations departments for TA support in the first half of 
2016, will have the following outputs: 
(i)  Crosscutting knowledge products and services released. The TA will support 
cross-sector,  crosscutting  knowledge  work,  including  but  not  limited  to  the 
following  topics:  water  (institutional  reform  of  water  agencies)  and  gender; 
governance  and  infrastructure  (open  government  initiatives  to  enhance 
infrastructure  delivery,  particularly  in  disaster-affected  areas);  environmental 
management and management of climate change and disaster risks (region-wide 
assessment  of  critical  infrastructure  and  risks from climate  change  impacts); 
education  and  infrastructure (for  skills  development,  technical  and  vocational 
education,  and  training  projects);  and  water,  agriculture,  and  energy  for  the 
water–food–energy nexus. 
(ii)  Timely  response  to  unplanned  developing  member  country  knowledge 
needs strengthened. The TA will support just-in-time delivery of KPS, as may 
be identified by ADB’s operations departments and resident missions, so that 
ADB can respond quickly and flexibly to changing or unforeseen circumstances 
and demands. This output will address the needs of resident mission country 
directors when additional technical expertise is required urgently.   
(iii)  Knowledge in new emerging areas and approaches applied. The TA will 
support (a) research on financing needs to deliver the social protection agenda of

4   
the SDGs (e.g., estimating the financial size of national social policy gaps in 
relation to the new SDGs, and exploring financing options to close national social 
protection policy gaps in the region); (b) a study of sustainable transport priorities 
of DMCs and potential donor partners (for financial or in-kind contributions) and 
the  application  of  new technologies  and  techniques  in  preparing  a financing 
partnership  facility  to  help  DMCs  achieve  sustainable  transport  and  meet 
financing  gaps;  and  (c)  a  health  study  on  innovative  universal  health-care 
projects, both nationally and subregionally. 
(iv)  Continuous learning (including co-learning), networking, and knowledge 
sharing for DMCs in partnership with k-hubs, centers of excellence, and 
external  partners  expanded.  The  TA  will  support  co-learning  training, 
networking and knowledge-sharing events for DMCs in partnership with k-hubs, 
COEs,  and  other  external  partners,  including  co-learning  with  DMC  officials 
during (a) Social Protection Week, which will include focus on the new SDGs; 
(b) a climate risk management workshop to quantify risks and recognize and 
implement  viable  climate  change  adaptation  responses  in  South  Asia; 
(c) partnership with local government units and COEs to develop actions plans 
(including legal frameworks and the institutional and financial capacity of local 
governments) and carry out activities to achieve SDG 16 (peace, justice, and 
strong  institutions)  with  a  focus  on  better  public  service  delivery;  and  (d)  a 
conference with the United Nations Environment Programme on sanitation, and a 
regional study on fundable projects and policy reforms in the Asia and Pacific 
region. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund ($590,000 from TASF-V and $910,000 from TASF-
other sources). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
10.  ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC), in close 
collaboration with the STGs and ADB’s regional departments, will have overall responsibility for 
TA  implementation.  The  Knowledge  Sharing  and  Services  Center  (KSSC)  in  SDCC,  in 
consultation with the Sector Advisory Service Division and the Social Development, Governance 
and Gender Division, will be responsible for receiving proposals from the STGs. Selection of the 
activities to be supported by the TA  will be the responsibility of the TA advisory group, including 
the senior director of the Sector Advisory Service Division; director of the Social Development, 
Governance and Gender Division; and advisor of the SDCC and head of the KSSC. Proposals 
for TA support during the first half of 2016 have been received, and have been summarized on 
an indicative basis (para. 8). To meet urgent, unanticipated, and catalytic demands from DMCs, 
proposals for just-in-time activities may be submitted by the regional departments or resident 
missions at any time through the relevant STGs. Proposals for TA support during the second 
half of 2016 will be solicited in March 2016. The STG or regional department or resident mission 
that submitted an approved proposal will be the “activity owner” and will be tasked to implement 
the proposed activity, including delivering the respective KPS and conducting related activities, 
such as recruiting consultants, substantiating disbursements, and/or seeking any counterpart 
support  from  government  agencies  concerned.  Given  the  role  of  ADB’s  KSSC  in  the 
development of knowledge platforms, such as k-Portal or k-Learn, as well as its responsibility 
for  sector  and  thematic  skills  development  programs,  KSSC  will  support  knowledge

5 
dissemination and leveraging of the resulting KPS. The TA is expected to be implemented from 
December 2015 to April 2017. 
 
11.  The principles and process in selecting TA activities are: 
(i)  A proposal can be prepared and submitted by ADB staff in her/his capacity as an 
STG member or regional department staff (including resident mission staff) for 
review  by  the  relevant  STG  chair(s)  and  technical  advisor(s).  The  proposal 
should indicate (a) the issues to be addressed in one or more DMCs; (b) the 
outputs and implementation arrangements, e.g., the coordination arrangements, 
as  relevant,  with  the  relevant  regional  department(s)  and  STG(s),  and  the 
timetable;  and  (c)  the  means  of  knowledge  sharing  and  dissemination  (as 
relevant). 
(ii)  All proposed products and activities must be included in the STGs’ work plans 
and/or  reflect  the  demands  of  DMCs,  as  confirmed  by  the  relevant regional 
department  through  the  country  partnership  strategies  and  CKPs,  and  the 
country  operations  business  plan’s  list  of  indicative  knowledge  products  and 
services (as appropriate). 
(iii)  Proposals  endorsed  by  the  STG  technical  advisor(s)  will  be  reviewed  and 
prioritized by the TA advisory group. The implementation capacity of the “activity 
owner,” including its ability and commitment to carry out activities on schedule 
and  within  budget,  substantiate  disbursements,  and  provide  a  brief  activity 
completion report, will be considered in the selection of proposals. 
 
12.  Based on indicative activities and discussions with the STGs and regional departments, 
about 32 person-months of international and 37 person-months of national consultants are 
expected to be needed to support TA activities and monitor the TA. These will include individual 
international and national consultants with relevant sector or thematic expertise. Consultants will 
be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as 
amended  from  time  to  time).  Contracts  will  be  on  an  output-based  or  lump-sum  basis. 
Disbursements under the TA will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
13.  To  ensure  efficient  and  effective  use  of  TA  funds,  terms  of  reference  and  project 
budgeting  will  be  required,  along  with  periodic  reporting  (including  financial)  on  activity 
implementation. SDCC will regularly communicate with the relevant STG members or regional 
department officers and be responsible for overall TA implementation, including the preparation 
of reports. The TA will be monitored by assessing quality and timely delivery of outputs. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis 
for Delivering Knowledge Solutions in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Individual consultants will be recruited, as necessary, to help carry out the sector and 
thematic group (STG) activities under the technical assistance (TA) (e.g., collaborative cross-
sector, nexus, and/or crosscutting work; flagship knowledge events and publications; research 
to inform future operations; and continuous learning, networking, and knowledge sharing with 
developing  member  countries, k-hubs, centers  of  excellence,  and  other  external  partners). 
Expertise, scope of work, and tasks will depend on the requirements of each activity. Each 
consultant will need to have the necessary technical expertise, and project and/or research 
experience. 
 
2.  Knowledge sharing and learning specialist (national, 8 person-months). A knowledge 
sharing and learning specialist will be recruited to help identify and act on opportunities to distill 
and develop knowledge products and services based on the STG activities supported by the TA. 
 
3.  Scope  of  work.  The  specialist  will  assess  the  TA-supported  STG  activities  and 
recommend knowledge products and services that can be developed or reused based on such 
activities. In consultation with the TA team leader and the Knowledge Sharing and Services 
Center (KSSC) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the specialist will then work with the 
ADB project officers (including the technical advisors and STG secretariat) and any consultant(s) 
responsible for such STG activities to produce such products and services, and leverage their 
impact, e.g., by including them in existing or new sector and/or thematic training programs, 
helping develop case studies, and sharing them on ADB knowledge platforms, such as k-Nexus, 
k-Learn, and k-Portal. The specialist will be recruited to work in ADB headquarters for 8 person-
months intermittently from December 2015 to April 2017.  
 
4.  Minimum qualification requirements. The specialist should have at least 5 years of 
relevant experience in knowledge sharing and dissemination, and designing and delivering 
learning programs. The specialist will work in, and will be a citizen of, the Philippines. 
 
5.  Technical  assistance  administration  consultant (national, 12 person-months). An 
experienced TA administration consultant will be recruited for 12 person-months intermittently in 
ADB headquarters from December 2015 to April 2017 to ensure smooth and expeditious TA 
implementation. The consultant will support the TA team leader and other KSSC staff, ADB 
officers in the relevant STGs and regional departments, and the other TA consultants. 
 
6.  Scope of work:  
(i)  Preparation of the TA implementation plan. 
(ii)  TA  coordination  with  the  relevant  STG  secretariats  regarding  consultant 
recruitment and monitoring of procurement (if any) carried out by the STGs. 
(iii)  Administrative support for international and national consultants, as needed. 
(iv)  Preparation of periodic progress reports and, if needed, assistance to the TA 
team leader in convening meetings. 
(v)  TA budget monitoring. 
(vi)  Support in preparing TA progress and other reports.  
(vii)  Ascertainment that TA information is published on the websites and/or in the e-
newsletters of ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department, 
the STGs, and regional departments in consultation with the TA team leader, 
knowledge sharing and learning specialist, and STG secretariats. 
(viii)  Consolidation of inputs required for the preparation of the TA completion report. 
(ix)  Performance of any other tasks required by the TA team leader.

Appendix 3  11 
 
7.  Minimum qualification requirements. The TA administration consultant should have at 
least 3 years of relevant project administration experience—e.g., preparation of logistics and 
implementation plans; budget preparation and monitoring; preparation of project financial and 
other implementation reports; preparation of materials to promote and share knowledge (e.g., e-
mail alerts, brochures, and website content); organization of meetings, workshops, and other 
events; interaction with ADB units to facilitate TA implementation; and use of standard Microsoft 
Office programs, such as Word, Excel, and PowerPoint. The consultant will work in, and will be 
a citizen of, the Philippines.
